content.text: This is a HE WSI of a CRC case, consisting of lymph nodes or primary tumor section. What is your initial impression of this image?

The thumbnail displays two large pieces of tissue, likely lymph nodes, almost entirely replaced by a basophilic (purple) infiltrate, which is highly suspicious for metastatic carcinoma. The surrounding tissue is adipose (fat). The lymph node on the left appears more irregular with some central pallor, while the one on the right is more ovoid and densely infiltrated. My first impression is that these are both positive (metastatic) lymph nodes.
Are there any places you want to look into further? Give me reasons why you want to look into each region.

I am zooming into this area on the left-hand lymph node because it appears to be a representative section of the tumor infiltrate. The area shows a high degree of cellularity and architectural complexity. Examining this region at high power is necessary to confirm the presence of malignant cells, identify their morphology (e.g., glandular formation), and assess their features, which is crucial for confirming a diagnosis of metastatic adenocarcinoma. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am zooming into the larger lymph node on the right to confirm the suspicion of metastasis. The selected area is strategically placed at the interface between the dense, dark purple cellular region and a paler, more varied area. This allows me to examine the morphology of the infiltrating cells, confirm they are malignant epithelial cells (carcinoma), and observe their interaction with the surrounding lymph node stroma and any residual lymphoid tissue. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found].
This is ROI 1 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, I see poorly formed, infiltrative glands composed of atypical epithelial cells set within a prominent desmoplastic stroma (dense pink fibrous tissue). There are also pools of extracellular mucin, which appear as pale, acellular material. The glandular cells show nuclear pleomorphism, hyperchromasia, and irregular contours. This morphology is characteristic of a metastatic adenocarcinoma with mucinous features, consistent with a colorectal primary. The impression is that this is a positive lymph node containing metastatic adenocarcinoma.
This is ROI 2 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in view clearly shows metastatic adenocarcinoma. There are infiltrative, irregularly shaped malignant glands and cell clusters embedded in a desmoplastic stroma. In the upper left portion of the image, there is a dense sheet of lymphocytes, which represents the remaining, compressed lymphoid tissue of the node. The clear demarcation between the invasive carcinoma and the residual lymphoid tissue confirms that this is a positive lymph node.
